title: John Locke
shortDescription: Father of Liberalism, foundational empiricist philosopher
biography: English philosopher and physician, known as the 'Father of Liberalism.' His empiricism (Essay Concerning Human Understanding) and political philosophy (Two Treatises of Government) established foundational concepts of natural rights, social contract, and religious toleration that influenced virtually all subsequent Enlightenment thinkers.

title: Isaac Newton
shortDescription: Natural philosopher who established mathematical physics
biography: English natural philosopher and mathematician whose Principia Mathematica established the mechanistic worldview and mathematical methodology that Enlightenment thinkers sought to extend to human affairs. Symbol of reason's triumph over scholasticism.

title: Gottfried Wilhelm Leibniz
shortDescription: Rationalist philosopher and co-inventor of calculus
biography: German philosopher, mathematician, and polymath. Co-inventor of calculus and rationalist philosopher. His optimism, monadology, and principle of sufficient reason shaped German philosophy through Wolff. Target of Voltaire's satire in Candide.

title: Voltaire
shortDescription: The quintessential philosophe and champion of civil liberties
biography: French writer, philosopher, and public intellectual. The quintessential philosophe with ~21,000 letters to ~1,800 correspondents. Championed civil liberties, freedom of religion, and free trade. Popularized Newton and Locke in France through works like Letters on the English.

title: Denis Diderot
shortDescription: Chief editor of the Encyclopédie and radical materialist
biography: French philosopher, art critic, and writer. Chief editor of the Encyclopédie (1751-1772), the defining project of the French Enlightenment. Wrote thousands of articles. Later developed radical materialist views in works like Le Neveu de Rameau.

title: Jean le Rond d'Alembert
shortDescription: Mathematician and co-editor of the Encyclopédie
biography: French mathematician, philosopher, and encyclopedist. Co-editor of Encyclopédie until 1758 and author of the famous Preliminary Discourse. Major mathematician who developed d'Alembert's principle. Permanent secretary of Académie française.

title: Montesquieu
alternateNames: Charles-Louis de Secondat, Baron de La Brède et de Montesquieu
shortDescription: Political philosopher who articulated separation of powers
biography: French political philosopher and jurist. The Spirit of the Laws (1748) articulated separation of powers and comparative political analysis. Profound influence on American constitutional framers through his analysis of republican government.

title: Jean-Jacques Rousseau
shortDescription: Controversial philosopher of the social contract and education
biography: Genevan philosopher, writer, and composer. Controversial figure whose Social Contract and Emile influenced political theory and education. His critique of civilization and ideas about the 'general will' made him both central and contested among philosophes.

title: Baron d'Holbach
shortDescription: Host of radical salon and systematic atheist philosopher
biography: German-born French philosopher and salon host. Host of the most radical salon of the Enlightenment ('la coterie holbachique'). Systematic atheist and materialist who published influential works like The System of Nature anonymously.

title: Claude-Adrien Helvétius
shortDescription: Philosopher whose utilitarian ethics influenced Bentham
biography: French philosopher and tax farmer. His De l'esprit (1758) caused scandal with its utilitarian, anti-religious ethics. The work was condemned by the Sorbonne and ordered burned. His ideas influenced Bentham's development of utilitarianism.

title: Étienne Bonnot de Condillac
biography: French philosopher and epistemologist. Developed Locke's empiricism into sensationalism—arguing all knowledge derives from transformed sensations. Major influence on French psychology and linguistics.

title: Nicolas de Condorcet
shortDescription: Mathematician who applied probability to social science
biography: French mathematician, philosopher, and political theorist. Bridged mathematics and social science, applying probability to voting theory (Condorcet paradox). Permanent Secretary of Académie des Sciences. Champion of women's rights, public education, and progress. Died during the French Revolution.

title: Julien Offray de La Mettrie
shortDescription: Radical materialist who argued humans are machines
biography: French physician and philosopher. Radical materialist who argued humans are machines (L'Homme Machine). Pushed Enlightenment materialism to its logical extreme. Found refuge at Frederick the Great's court after exile from France and Netherlands.

title: Louis de Jaucourt
shortDescription: Most prolific Encyclopédie contributor with 17,288 articles
biography: French encyclopedist and physician. Most prolific contributor to the Encyclopédie—wrote approximately 17,288 articles (about 25% of total text) on topics from medicine to politics. Worked unpaid, sacrificing his personal fortune for the project.

title: Étienne Noël Damilaville
shortDescription: Key intermediary in philosophe correspondence network
biography: French tax official and intermediary in the philosophe network. Helped circulate letters and clandestine texts when censorship made direct communication difficult, using his position in tax administration to facilitate correspondence.

title: André Morellet
shortDescription: Economist and translator of Adam Smith
biography: French economist, writer, and translator. Translated Adam Smith's Wealth of Nations into French. Contributed to Encyclopédie on theology and philosophy. Member of d'Holbach's circle. Lived through the Revolution and wrote memoirs of salon culture.

title: David Hume
shortDescription: Greatest empiricist philosopher whose skepticism awakened Kant
biography: Scottish philosopher, historian, and essayist. Greatest empiricist philosopher whose skepticism about causation and religion profoundly influenced Kant ('awakened from dogmatic slumber'). His friendship with Adam Smith was central to the Scottish Enlightenment.

title: Adam Smith
shortDescription: Founder of classical economics and moral philosopher
biography: Scottish moral philosopher and economist. Founded classical economics with Wealth of Nations. His moral philosophy (Theory of Moral Sentiments) was deeply influenced by Hume. Central figure linking philosophy and economics.

title: Francis Hutcheson
biography: Irish-Scottish philosopher and professor. 'Father of the Scottish Enlightenment.' His moral sense theory influenced Hume and Smith. Teacher of Adam Smith at Glasgow, establishing the foundation for Scottish moral philosophy.

title: Thomas Reid
shortDescription: Founder of Scottish Common Sense philosophy
biography: Scottish philosopher. Founder of Scottish Common Sense philosophy. Criticized Hume's skepticism, arguing humans have reliable innate beliefs. Succeeded Adam Smith as Professor at Glasgow. Major influence on American philosophy.

title: Adam Ferguson
shortDescription: Pioneer of sociology and analyst of civil society
biography: Scottish philosopher and historian. Pioneer of sociology ('father of sociology'). Analyzed civil society and warned about commercial society's effects on civic virtue in his Essay on the History of Civil Society.

title: William Robertson
shortDescription: Leading historian and Principal of Edinburgh University
biography: Scottish historian, clergyman, and administrator. Leading historian of the British Enlightenment. Principal of University of Edinburgh (1762-1793), reforming its curriculum and reputation. One of Britain's most widely read historians in Europe.

title: Henry Home, Lord Kames
shortDescription: Patron and mentor to Scottish Enlightenment figures
biography: Scottish judge, philosopher, and agricultural improver. Patron and mentor to many Scottish Enlightenment figures. Wrote on law, aesthetics, and morality. Employed young Adam Smith and encouraged Hume, helping establish Edinburgh's intellectual culture.

title: Dugald Stewart
shortDescription: Transmitted Scottish philosophy to the 19th century
biography: Scottish philosopher. Transmitted Scottish Enlightenment philosophy to the 19th century. Biographer of Smith and Reid. Taught many influential students, bridging the Enlightenment to later philosophical developments.

title: Immanuel Kant
shortDescription: Synthesized rationalism and empiricism in critical philosophy
biography: German philosopher. Synthesized rationalism and empiricism in critical philosophy. His essay 'What is Enlightenment?' (1784) defined the movement: 'Sapere aude' (Dare to know). The three Critiques transformed philosophy.

title: Christian Wolff
biography: German philosopher and mathematician. Dominant German philosopher before Kant. Systematized Leibniz's ideas into a rationalist system that dominated German universities until Kant's critical turn. Expelled from Halle by Pietists in 1723, recalled by Frederick the Great.

title: Moses Mendelssohn
shortDescription: Leading figure of German and Jewish Enlightenment
biography: German philosopher and Jewish community leader. Leading figure of German Enlightenment and Jewish Haskalah (Jewish Enlightenment). Championed religious tolerance and Jewish emancipation. Called the 'German Socrates.' Both he and Kant answered 'What is Enlightenment?' in 1784.

title: Gotthold Ephraim Lessing
biography: German writer, dramatist, and critic. Germany's greatest Enlightenment dramatist. Championed religious tolerance in Nathan the Wise. Major literary and aesthetic critic whose Laocoon distinguished temporal from spatial arts.

title: Johann Gottfried Herder
biography: German philosopher, theologian, and literary critic. Transitional figure toward Romanticism. Emphasized culture, language, history, and Volksgeist (national spirit). Critiqued abstract Enlightenment universalism while studying under Kant.

title: Alexander Gottlieb Baumgarten
shortDescription: Founded aesthetics as a philosophical discipline
biography: German philosopher. Founded aesthetics as a philosophical discipline—his Aesthetica coined the term. Influenced Kant's aesthetic theory; Kant used his Metaphysica as a teaching text.

title: Johann Wolfgang von Goethe
biography: German writer, poet, natural philosopher, and statesman. Germany's greatest literary figure. Early works (Sorrows of Young Werther, Götz von Berlichingen) sparked Sturm und Drang movement. Transitional figure between Enlightenment and Romanticism. Lifelong friendship with Herder.

title: George Berkeley
biography: Irish philosopher and Anglican bishop. Developed idealist empiricism: 'to be is to be perceived.' Critiqued Locke's theory of abstract ideas. His arguments influenced Hume's development of skepticism.

title: Anthony Ashley Cooper, 3rd Earl of Shaftesbury
biography: English philosopher and politician. Developed moral sense theory—humans have innate moral sentiments. Influenced Hutcheson and through him the Scottish school. Educated by Locke but later critiqued his rejection of innate ideas.

title: Bernard Mandeville
shortDescription: Satirist who argued private vices produce public benefits
biography: Dutch-born English philosopher and satirist. The Fable of the Bees argued private vices produce public benefits—a scandal that influenced economic thought. Provoked Hutcheson's moral philosophy and influenced Smith's economics.

title: Edmund Burke
shortDescription: Conservative critic of the French Revolution
biography: Irish-born British statesman and political philosopher. Leading conservative critic of the French Revolution (Reflections). Earlier work on aesthetics (Sublime and Beautiful) influenced Kant. Represents Enlightenment's limits and counter-currents.

title: Joseph Priestley
shortDescription: Scientist who discovered oxygen and religious dissenter
biography: English scientist, theologian, and political theorist. Discovered oxygen independently. Materialist, determinist, religious dissenter who championed toleration, education reform, and individual liberty. Birmingham Riots destroyed his home; fled to America.

title: Jeremy Bentham
biography: English philosopher and legal reformer. Founder of utilitarianism—'greatest happiness of the greatest number.' Developed systematic approach to legal and social reform. Influenced by Helvétius and Beccaria.

title: Thomas Paine
biography: English-born American political theorist and pamphleteer. Most widely read Enlightenment radical. Common Sense catalyzed American independence. Rights of Man defended French Revolution. Age of Reason promoted deism. Bridged American, British, and French revolutionary discourse.

title: Cesare Beccaria
biography: Italian jurist and philosopher. On Crimes and Punishments (1764) revolutionized criminal justice—opposed torture and death penalty, promoted proportional punishment. Major influence on legal reform across Europe and America.

title: François Quesnay
shortDescription: Founder of Physiocracy and economic science
biography: French physician and economist. Founder of Physiocracy—first systematic school of economics. Developed Tableau économique modeling economic flows. Court physician to Madame de Pompadour and Louis XV. Contributed economic articles to Encyclopédie.

title: Anne-Robert-Jacques Turgot
biography: French economist and administrator. Attempted Enlightenment economic reforms as Controller-General—free trade in grain, abolition of guilds. Major economic theorist beyond strict Physiocracy. Reform efforts blocked by vested interests; dismissed 1776.

title: Victor de Riqueti, Marquis de Mirabeau
biography: French economist and political writer. Leading Physiocrat who coined the term 'civilization.' Father of the revolutionary leader Mirabeau. Called 'Friend of Mankind'—one of most widely read economic writers.

title: Benjamin Franklin
biography: American scientist, diplomat, inventor, and writer. Exemplar of Enlightenment values—scientist, inventor, self-made man. His electrical experiments brought international fame. In Paris, bridged American and French Enlightenment.

title: Thomas Jefferson
biography: American statesman, philosopher, and architect. Author of Declaration of Independence. Minister to France, immersed in philosophe circles. Embodied Enlightenment ideals of reason, natural rights, and religious freedom.

title: James Madison
biography: American statesman and political theorist. 'Father of the Constitution.' Applied Enlightenment political theory (especially Montesquieu) to constitutional design. Federalist Papers are a classic of political philosophy.

title: John Adams
biography: American statesman and political theorist. Constitutional theorist emphasizing balanced government. More skeptical of human nature than Jefferson. Ambassador to Britain; met philosophes in Paris.

title: Leonhard Euler
biography: Swiss mathematician. Most prolific mathematician in history. Worked at Berlin Academy under Frederick the Great. Advanced calculus, number theory, mechanics, optics. Returned to Russia in 1766 after conflicts with Frederick.

title: Pierre-Simon Laplace
shortDescription: Developed celestial mechanics and probability theory
biography: French mathematician and astronomer. Developed celestial mechanics and probability theory. When asked about God's role in his system, reportedly said: 'I had no need of that hypothesis.'

title: Antoine Lavoisier
biography: French chemist. 'Father of modern chemistry.' Identified oxygen's role in combustion, established chemical nomenclature. Member of Académie des Sciences. Guillotined during the Terror despite scientific eminence.

title: Georges-Louis Leclerc, Comte de Buffon
shortDescription: Naturalist whose work was most widely read scientific text
biography: French naturalist. Histoire naturelle (44 volumes) was most widely read scientific work of the century. Speculated on earth's age and species transformation, challenging biblical timescales diplomatically.

title: Émilie du Châtelet
shortDescription: Translator of Newton's Principia into French
biography: French natural philosopher, mathematician, and translator. Translated Newton's Principia into French (still the standard French translation). Collaborated with Voltaire on Newtonian physics. Important scientist in her own right.

title: Joseph-Louis Lagrange
biography: Italian-French mathematician and astronomer. One of the greatest mathematicians of the 18th century. Developed calculus of variations, Lagrangian mechanics. Succeeded Euler at Berlin Academy.

title: Marie-Thérèse Rodet Geoffrin
shortDescription: Hosted the most influential Enlightenment salon
biography: French salon hostess. Hosted one of the most influential Enlightenment salons. Financially supported the Encyclopédie. Connected philosophes with aristocrats and foreigners. Monday dinners for artists, Wednesday for philosophes.

title: Julie de Lespinasse
shortDescription: Salon hostess with close ties to encyclopedists
biography: French salon hostess. Hosted salon frequented by encyclopedists and philosophes. Very close relationship with d'Alembert, who lived in her house. Former companion to Madame du Deffand before establishing rival salon.

title: Marie de Vichy-Chamrond, Marquise du Deffand
biography: French salon hostess and letter-writer. Hosted literary salon for decades. Famous correspondence with Voltaire and Horace Walpole. Went blind in 1752 but continued salon through dictated letters.

title: Anne-Catherine de Ligniville
shortDescription: Salon hostess connecting American and French Enlightenment
biography: French salon hostess. After husband's death (1771), continued influential salon at Auteuil. Franklin was close friend (proposed marriage). Connected American visitors to French intellectuals.

title: Frederick II of Prussia
shortDescription: Model enlightened despot and patron of philosophers
biography: King of Prussia and patron of arts and philosophy. Model 'enlightened despot.' Corresponded with Voltaire, hosted him (1750-53). Revitalized Berlin Academy. Patron of Euler and La Mettrie. Wrote Anti-Machiavel.

title: Catherine II of Russia
biography: Empress of Russia. Corresponded with Voltaire and Diderot. Purchased Diderot's library (letting him keep it). Attempted Enlightenment-inspired reforms. Called Voltaire 'my master.'

shortDescription: Established mathematical physics and the mechanistic worldview

title: Introduction to the Principles of Morals and Legislation

title: Rational Thoughts on God, the World, and the Soul of Man

title: Aesthetica

title: Metaphysica

title: Treatise on the Origin of Language

title: Critique of Pure Reason

title: Jerusalem, or On Religious Power and Judaism
shortDescription: Defense of Jewish practice and church-state separation

title: Ideas for the Philosophy of History of Humanity

title: Declaration of Independence
shortDescription: Applied Lockean natural rights to justify revolution

shortDescription: Standard French translation still used today
